metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: Explain and analyse examples of special relativity including that: muons can reach Earth even though their half-lives would suggest that they should decay in the upper atmosphere; particle accelerator lengths must be designed to take the effects of special relativity into account; time signals from GPS satellites must be corrected for the effects of special relativity due to their orbital velocity

muon_time_dilation_earth_frame.name: Muon Time Dilation (Earth Frame)
muon_time_dilation_earth_frame.correct: From Earth's frame, the muon's clock runs slow. Earth observes the muon's half-life as dilated (longer), allowing more muons to survive.

the muon experiences time slowing down.error: The muon experiences its own time normally. Dilation is what Earth OBSERVES.
the muon experiences time slowing down.fix: The muon's proper time is 2.2 Œºs. Earth observes this dilated to ~22 Œºs for Œ≥ = 10.
the muon experiences time slowing down.action: Key distinction: dilation is observational, not experiential.

the muon ages faster.error: Opposite. Dilated time means the muon ages LESS as observed by Earth.
the muon ages faster.fix: Fewer muon-seconds pass (as Earth observes), so the muon ages less.
the muon ages faster.action: t = Œ≥t‚ÇÄ means more Earth-seconds pass than muon-seconds.

time dilation shortens the half-life.error: Dilation lengthens the observed half-life, not shortens it.
time dilation shortens the half-life.fix: Dilated = stretched. The observed half-life is longer, not shorter.
time dilation shortens the half-life.action: Calculate: if t‚ÇÄ = 2.2 Œºs and Œ≥ = 10, what is t?

persistent.gap: You're confusing what the observer sees with what the moving object experiences.
persistent.action: Memorise: P observes D's clock running slow. D experiences normal time.

muon_length_contraction_muon_frame.name: Muon Length Contraction (Muon Frame)
muon_length_contraction_muon_frame.correct: From the muon's frame, the distance to Earth is contracted. The muon experiences its normal half-life but travels a shorter distance.

the muon sees its own length contracted.error: The muon doesn't contract. The DISTANCE to Earth contracts in its frame.
the muon sees its own length contracted.fix: Length contraction applies to objects moving relative to the observer.
the muon sees its own length contracted.action: From the muon's frame, Earth is moving toward it, so Earth's distance is contracted.

the muon experiences a longer path.error: Opposite. Contraction shortens the path in the muon's frame.
the muon experiences a longer path.fix: L = L‚ÇÄ/Œ≥ gives a shorter distance for Œ≥ > 1.
the muon experiences a longer path.action: If L‚ÇÄ = 10 km and Œ≥ = 10, what is L?

length contraction doesn't apply to muon.error: Length contraction applies to all relativistic scenarios.
length contraction doesn't apply to muon.fix: Both time dilation and length contraction explain muon survival‚Äîfrom different frames.
length contraction doesn't apply to muon.action: Try both approaches: Earth frame uses time dilation, muon frame uses length contraction.

persistent.gap: You're not applying length contraction correctly to reference frames.
persistent.action: In muon's frame: muon is stationary, Earth moves ‚Üí distance is contracted.

muon_survival_explanation.name: Muon Survival Explanation
muon_survival_explanation.formula: Classical: d = vt‚ÇÄ; Relativistic: d = vŒ≥t‚ÇÄ
muon_survival_explanation.correct: Classical physics predicts muons decay after ~660 m. Relativity explains how they travel ~6600 m to reach Earth's surface.

muons travel faster than light.fix: Relativity extends their observed lifetime, not their speed.
muons travel faster than light.action: v ‚âà 0.995c is fast but still below c.

classical physics is completely wrong.fix: At v << c, classical and relativistic predictions converge.
classical physics is completely wrong.action: Compare predictions at v = 0.1c vs v = 0.995c.

muons don't actually decay.error: Muons still decay‚Äîthey just survive longer as observed from Earth.
muons don't actually decay.fix: The half-life is still 2.2 Œºs in the muon's frame. Earth observes it dilated.
muons don't actually decay.action: More muons survive, but they still decay eventually.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding why classical predictions fail at high speeds.
persistent.action: Calculate classical distance (v √ó t‚ÇÄ) vs relativistic distance (v √ó Œ≥t‚ÇÄ).

accelerator_length_contraction.name: Accelerator Length Contraction
accelerator_length_contraction.correct: From a particle's frame, the accelerator length is contracted. Engineers must design longer accelerators to compensate.

particles see a longer accelerator.error: Particles see a SHORTER accelerator due to length contraction.
particles see a longer accelerator.fix: L = L‚ÇÄ/Œ≥ gives L < L‚ÇÄ when Œ≥ > 1.

accelerator_design_implications.name: Accelerator Design Implications
accelerator_design_implications.correct: Particle accelerators must be built to their proper length in the lab frame, which is longer than what particles experience.

only circular accelerators need relativi.fix: The Stanford Linear Accelerator is 3.2 km precisely because of length contraction.

persistent.action: Practice: calculate required accelerator length for different Œ≥ values.

gps_time_dilation.name: GPS Time Dilation
gps_time_dilation.formula: t = Œ≥t‚ÇÄ (satellite clocks run slow as observed from Earth)
gps_time_dilation.correct: From Earth's frame, GPS satellite clocks run slow due to their orbital velocity. Clocks are adjusted to tick faster to compensate.

satellite clocks run fast.error: Due to special relativity alone, satellite clocks run SLOW as observed from Earth.
satellite clocks run fast.fix: Moving clocks run slow. GPS satellites move at ~4 km/s relative to Earth.
satellite clocks run fast.action: Note: general relativity causes them to run fast, but SR causes them to run slow.

clocks are adjusted to tick slower.fix: If SR makes them appear slow by 7 Œºs/day, pre-adjust them to tick 7 Œºs/day faster.

gps_correction_necessity.name: GPS Correction Necessity
gps_correction_necessity.correct: Without relativistic corrections, GPS would accumulate ~7 Œºs/day error from SR, causing ~2 km daily position drift.

GPS works without any corrections.error: GPS would fail within minutes without relativistic corrections.
GPS works without any corrections.fix: After 2 minutes, errors would make GPS highly inaccurate.

corrections are only applied on the grou.error: Satellite clocks are pre-adjusted before launch AND ground receivers apply corrections.
corrections are only applied on the grou.fix: Both ends of the system account for relativistic effects.
corrections are only applied on the grou.action: Research how GPS satellites are calibrated before launch.

general relativity is more important tha.fix: SR effect is smaller but still significant for precision.
general relativity is more important tha.action: Note: we only study SR in VCE, but know GR also contributes.

persistent.gap: You underestimate how relativistic effects accumulate over time.
persistent.action: Map out: 7 Œºs/day ‚Üí 2.5 ms/year ‚Üí several km annual drift without corrections.

frame_symmetry.name: Reference Frame Symmetry
frame_symmetry.formula: Both observers see other's clock as slow
frame_symmetry.correct: Both Earth and the muon see the other's clock as running slow. This symmetry is fundamental to special relativity.

only one observer sees time dilation.error: Both observers see the OTHER's clock as dilated.
only one observer sees time dilation.fix: Earth sees muon's clock slow; muon sees Earth's clock slow. Both are correct.
only one observer sees time dilation.action: Draw the symmetry: P sees D slow, D sees P slow.

one frame is more correct than another.error: No preferred frame exists. All inertial frames are equally valid.
one frame is more correct than another.fix: This is Einstein's first postulate: laws of physics are the same in all inertial frames.
one frame is more correct than another.action: Explain muon survival from BOTH frames‚Äîboth explanations are valid.

time dilation only happens to moving obj.error: Motion is relative. Each observer considers themselves stationary.
time dilation only happens to moving obj.fix: From the muon's view, Earth is moving. From Earth's view, the muon is moving.
time dilation only happens to moving obj.action: Practice describing the same event from both reference frames.

persistent.gap: You're treating one frame as privileged or absolute.
persistent.action: For any relativity problem, explain from both frames. Both must work.

proper_time_identification.name: Proper Time Identification
proper_time_identification.formula: t‚ÇÄ measured where events occur at same location
proper_time_identification.correct: Proper time is measured by an observer for whom both events occur at the same point in space.

always measured by Earth.fix: For muon creation/decay, the muon measures proper time (events at same location).
always measured by Earth.action: Ask: where do both events occur? That observer measures proper time.

measured by the moving observer.error: Motion is relative. Proper time is defined by spatial coincidence of events.
measured by the moving observer.fix: Proper time is measured by whoever sees both events at the same location.
measured by the moving observer.action: For muon: birth and death happen at the muon's location ‚Üí muon measures t‚ÇÄ.

persistent.action: Proper time = events at same location for that observer. Find who that is.

proper_length_identification.name: Proper Length Identification
proper_length_identification.formula: L‚ÇÄ measured when object is at rest
proper_length_identification.correct: Proper length is measured by an observer at rest relative to the object being measured.

the shorter length.fix: L = L‚ÇÄ/Œ≥ and Œ≥ ‚â• 1, so L ‚â§ L‚ÇÄ. Proper length is always largest.

always measured by the moving observer.fix: For the accelerator, lab scientists measure proper length (at rest relative to it).

persistent.gap: You're confusing proper length with contracted length.
persistent.action: At rest relative to object ‚Üí proper length. Moving relative to object ‚Üí contracted length.

classical_vs_relativistic.name: Classical vs Relativistic Predictions
classical_vs_relativistic.formula: Classical fails when v approaches c
classical_vs_relativistic.correct: Classical physics predicts muons travel ~660 m before decay. Relativistic physics correctly predicts ~6600 m, matching observations.

classical physics is always wrong.fix: When v << c, Œ≥ ‚âà 1, and relativistic equations reduce to classical ones.

muons don't actually reach Earth.fix: Experiments confirm: ~12% of muons survive the journey when Œ≥ ‚âà 7.
muons don't actually reach Earth.action: Research Rossi-Hall experiment confirming muon survival.
